comment: I’m studying for the MCAT and Le Chatelier’s Principle is one of the main concepts and topics tested so I’m learning 🤗
8:35 may become little bit confising K=P(p4)/(P(p2))^2 Q(now)=2*P(p4)/(2*P(p2))^2=2/2^2 * P(p4)/(P(p2))^2=0.5 * K so, Q=0.5*K => Q<K
This lecture gave me both qualitative intuition and guide to quantitative expression on this topic. The introduction of actual application also helped me a lot. Thx Prof. Drenner!
I'm studying this chapter in 11 standard

That was massively confusing to me, because the symbols don't mean what I expected.  I'm pretty sure that when I saw this stuff before, the superscript zero in things like delta-G-nought meant standard conditions.  It doesn't mean that here.  It's what I think would have been indicated by superscript "0,T": standard concentrations, but whatever temperature you happen to be at.
I like all lectures to have some demo to go along.  This is all abstract. I do not think it is hard material but it is boring
So how can it be that when you add new gas, both the pressure and volume keep constant. Unless you are implying temperature change, it can't be.

15:51 the clicker question can have two answers,both 1 and 2 would be correct since it was not mentioned in the question we can also assume the volume was kept constant aswell if the volume of the container was also kept constant, then the reaction would need to shift towards the products to keep the total pressure constant.. so the 2nd answer is correct aswell

The lesson is pretty clear (at least to me). I'm still studying this content on my high school and i can assure you that this teacher is really good. I would encourage all of you who may not understand the topics to keep on trying by using books. Videos are   complementary.
I would like to comment on the clothing that both teachers wear. Both are wearing fractal patterns. Would anyone else like to comment on this?
